behaviour.feedbackOnCorrect: This is correct! Middlesex county has an estimated 1.6 million people living in it.
behaviour.feedbackOnWrong: Not quite, Middlesex county actually has an estimated 1.6 million people living it it, the largest county in Massachusetts.

params.question: Concept Check: Middlesex has the largest estimated total population according to the above figure.

behaviour.feedbackOnCorrect: This is correct!  It is actually Suffolk County that has the highest estimated proportion of people impacted by poverty relative to its total population (n= 256,384/801,200)
behaviour.feedbackOnWrong: While Middlesex county does have a substantial amount of people experiencing poverty (16%)-- relative to its total population of 1.6 million it is still a bit smaller than other counties in terms of proportion of population impacted (n=256,000).

params.question: Middlesex County also has the highest proption of people impacted by poverty.

behaviour.feedbackOnCorrect: This is correct! More often than not poverty is inequitably distributed across an area, with other risk factors such as educational status, race/ethnicity, employment status and geography (rural/urban) status being key predictors of where poverty may be concentrated. This is a likewise a key association for us to keep in mind as we think about how poverty impacts lead service line distribution.
behaviour.feedbackOnWrong: Not quite. In an area like Suffolk County, different cities may be more or less likely to experience poverty in various rates. Consider a suburb like Newton (Poverty Rate: ~4%) vs a more urban area such as Roxbury (Poverty Rate ~25%).

params.question: Poverty experienced by a area (in this case a county) is usually equally distributed across everyone in the area.
